posts.cooked: One of our SparkMaxes isn’t getting any power and even after changing the sparkMax out for a different one neither one is working and we did check the continuity of the power wires that connect to the spark max from the PDH and they were receiving power. All wiring looks the same for each sparkMax as the one we’re having a problem with. We have confirmed it’s something with the SparkMax itself by plugging it into our computer to check the rev hardware client. Does anybody know how to fix this other than just replacing it?

link_counts.title: Best (easiest) way to connect (wire and program) Thrifty Absolute Magnetic Encoder to REV SPARK MAX Motor Controller?

posts.name: Rishabh
posts.cooked: We had this same issue during season, there was some cross wiring that was causing the spark max to fry. I would recommend redoing the wiring for that spark max, you can confirm that it’s a wire issue if you open up the spark max and see one of the chips contacts had come lose.
Well we even tried another sparkMax and had the same issue with that one. I know the second one was never used because none of the wires had ever been stripped for use.

posts.name: Tom
posts.cooked:
Are you connecting the sparkmax to the motor (assuming NEO?) before powering on the robot?

If so, please do NOT connect the motor when trying a new spark max. If the spark gets power, it is a motor side wiring issue that can kill the spark forever.

NEO Motors Permanently Destroy Spark MAX — Symptoms to Watch For Technical

link_counts.title: NEO Motors Permanently Destroy Spark MAX — Symptoms to Watch For

posts.cooked: Can you provide a picture of how the SparkMax is wired? If you are unable to power it, can you still see it over the hardware client? I am not familiar with that side of things.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
That’s sounding like an Anderson pin on the supply side where the tab isn’t all the way in…  Deploy your “sensible tug” skills

+1 on the check all the chain from your power distribution to the SparkMax.  You could have a short strip on one of the power wires too.

Power and frying the spark max issues aside, I take that it isn’t showing up in rev hardware client over usb?

If it is showing up, then ignore this comment, it’s likely something else, but if it isn’t showing up at all, try powering it up in recovery mode (hold down the mode button while powering the spark max, connect over usb), and update it, as perhaps the firmware got corrupted.

posts.name: Eyup Akgun
posts.cooked: This is really sad. My team bought 10 spark max motor drivers this year but 3 of them are faulty. Luckily we were able to fix it. Most teams are experiencing this but they still keep sending defective spark

Thank you! I didn’t know about this issue and will see if this is the problem with ours as soon as I get back to our shop. As it is off-season we only meet once a week so it’ll be a few days before I can test it.

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked: The root cause was a short between the green encoder cable wire (which is actually a temperature sensor) and the encoder cable power wire, which permanently damaged the Spark MAX.  We destroyed 3 Spark MAX at championship before realizing the motor itself was killing it and had to be replaced.
That would explain it getting fried after the motor got hot. We didn’t know what was causing it to heat up so we didn’t know what to fix.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Did you confirm that it was a short between the encoder cable wires, or might it have been green wire to a -motor- wire?  I ask because the temperature sensor is buried in the windings…

Do you HAVE the bad motor?  Can I pay shipping to get it?  I’d like to work out an addition to my motor tester to detect this failure mode!  And, of course, modify the tester so it prevents this from happening while you identify it
We had similar issues, appeared the power intermittency was between the controller and motor. We replaced all the Andersen connectors with Posi-Lock connectors and never had issues since.

posts.name: seg9585
posts.cooked: Sorry yes you’re right, the short was between the temp sensor and a motor wire, not directly to the encoder power wire.  I did mean to ship this motor to you for evaluation, which I will do ASAP!  I do have it at home  (but currently on business travel so I can ship it out in a couple weeks).

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: No worries, I’m in business travel hell these days too!
